{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19341,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gnidia pinifolia prefers well-drained soil and does not like to sit in water, so keeping the soil slightly dry between waterings is crucial. Watering should be done moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has drainage holes to allow excess water to escape. Frequency of watering may vary depending on the climate and season; reduce watering in the cooler months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gnidia pinifolia thrives in a location where it can receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should get at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to support healthy growth and blooming. If grown in an area with very hot, intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. Ensure the plant has enough light to maintain its vibrant foliage but avoid extremes of constant direct sunlight that may harm it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gnidia pinifolia involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to promote healthy growth and maintain its shape. This should be done in early spring before the new growth starts. Avoid excessive pruning, as this plant can be sensitive and excessive cutting back might disrupt its growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission. Pruning also encourages more branching and fuller growth, so light trimming of the tips of healthy branches can also be beneficial."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Needle Capesaffron","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Needle Capesaffron"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Gnidia pinifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18152,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aristolochia rotunda prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. Watering should be done regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. Make sure the pot or garden soil is well-draining to avoid standing water. In drier, hot conditions, you may need to water more frequently. During the colder months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aristolochia rotunda thrives in a location that provides partial shade to full sun. It can tolerate direct sunlight but prefers a few hours of indirect or dappled light, especially during the hottest parts of the day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window, but make sure it's protected from harsh midday sun. Adequate light helps maintain healthy growth and vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aristolochia rotunda is not mandatory but can be done to manage its size and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves. If the plant becomes too leggy, you can trim back the longer stems to promote a more compact growth habit. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to minimize damage and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smearwort","description":"Aristolochia rotunda, commonly known as smearwort or round-leaved birthwort, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Southern Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Smearwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aristolochia rotunda"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18946,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elegia tectorum, commonly known as Cape Thatch Reed, prefers consistently moist soil. It is crucial to keep the plant well-watered without allowing the soil to dry out completely. During its active growing season, water the plant regularly to maintain moist conditions, but reduce watering in the winter when the plant is dormant. Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. If planted in a garden setting, regular checking of soil moisture levels is recommended, especially during hot, dry spells, to ensure the plant remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elegia tectorum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. To ensure optimal growth, provide this plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In very hot climates, it may benefit from partial shade during the hottest part of the day to prevent scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample bright light. However, avoid locations where there might be direct midday sun, which can be too intense and may cause leaf burn. Proper sunlight exposure is key to maintaining its lush, green appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Elegia tectorum involves removing dead, damaged, or old stems to encourage new growth and maintain its attractive appearance. This can be done during the late winter or early spring before the growing season begins. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to cut the stems at the base. This plant naturally forms dense clumps, so thinning out crowded stems can also help increase air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Regular pruning not only maintains aesthetics but also encourages the plant's health and vigor by directing energy towards new and healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cape Thatching Reed","description":"Elegia tectorum, previously Chondropetalum tectorum or Restio tectorum, more commonly Cape thatching reed, or dakriet (in Afrikaans), is a member of the restio family, Restionaceae. It is a tufted perennial growing to between 1.5 and 2.25 m, with deciduous leaf sheaths. Flowers are less than 3 mm long. Petals are smooth or hairy in the upper half. E. tectorum is found in marshes and seeps on deep sand in the Western Cape and Eastern Cape of...","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Thatching Reed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Elegia tectorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19542,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brunia paleacea, native to the fynbos regions of South Africa, thrives best in conditions that mimic its natural arid environment. This means it requires minimal watering, especially during the dry months. It's crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant sparingly but more frequently, ensuring the soil is well-drained. In winter, when the plant is less active, reduce watering significantly, possibly once a month, depending on humidity levels and indoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brunia paleacea requires full sun to thrive, as it is accustomed to the bright and intense sunlight of the South African fynbos. Ideal growing conditions include six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. If keeping the plant indoors or in a region with lower sunlight intensity, consider placing it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in leggy growth and reduced floral production. Supplement lighting with grow lights if necessary during shorter days."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brunia paleacea is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to remove any dead or decaying branches, as well as any crossing or overcrowded branches inside the plant's canopy. Regular pruning helps in maintaining aeration within the plant, preventing fungal diseases. Be cautious not to cut into the main woody stems, as this can harm the plant; instead, focus on trimming back softer, younger growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Spikekol","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Spikekol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Brunia paleacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19734,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fomitopsis betulina is a type of fungus, commonly known as the birch polypore, rather than a traditional plant. In general, fungi don't require watering in the usual sense like plants do. They grow on trees, particularly birch trees, and draw their nutrients and moisture directly from their host. To support its growth in cultivation, maintain an environment with moderate humidity and moisture typical of a decaying wood habitat. If growing in a controlled environment, ensure the substrate remains slightly moist but not waterlogged to mimic natural conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fomitopsis betulina typically grows in shaded or partially shaded environments, as it naturally occurs on birch trees in forests. Direct sunlight is not necessary for its development, as it relies on the cooler, damp conditions under the forest canopy. If you’re cultivating this fungus, mimic its natural habitat by providing dappled shade or indirect light to prevent drying out and dying. Maintaining a consistent temperature as found in temperate climates will be beneficial for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Fomitopsis betulina is a fungus and not a plant, conventional pruning is not applicable. However, harvesting techniques can be employed if the fungus is cultivated or collected. To sustainably harvest, carefully cut the fruiting body at its base while leaving the mycelium intact to ensure continued growth. It’s important to minimize damage to the host tree and surrounding mycelium. Regularly monitor for additional growth or decay which might need removal in managed environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"birch polypore","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["birch polypore"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Fomitopsis betulina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18443,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cottsia gracilis, commonly known as Slender Greenthread, prefers well-draining soil and moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, so it should be allowed to dry out between waterings. Water deeply, ensuring the roots get adequately hydrated, but avoid waterlogging the plant as it can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, regular watering is beneficial. However, be sure to reduce the frequency in fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cottsia gracilis thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It is best to provide it with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth and flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. This plant is adaptable and can also tolerate partial shade, but flowering might be reduced with less sunlight. Ensuring adequate sunlight will help maintain its vibrant growth and prolong the blooming period during its season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cottsia gracilis is generally minimal but beneficial to promote healthy growth and blooming. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased stems to keep the plant looking tidy. Pruning is best done in early spring before new growth begins. If necessary, you can lightly trim back any overgrown or leggy stems, as this will encourage bushier growth. Be sure to use sharp and clean pruning shears to avoid any damage to the plant. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can also keep the plant looking fresh and stimulate additional blooming."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"slender janusia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["slender janusia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Cottsia gracilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19043,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erysiphe alphitoides is not a plant, but a species of fungus commonly known for causing powdery mildew, particularly on oak trees. In terms of managing its impact, maintaining proper tree hydration is crucial. Ensure trees are adequately watered during dry periods, helping them maintain vigor and resist infections. However, avoid overhead watering which can create moist conditions that promote fungal growth. Instead, use drip irrigation or water at the base of the tree to minimize leaf moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Managing sunlight exposure can help control the spread of Erysiphe alphitoides by reducing humidity levels, thereby hindering the growth of this powdery mildew. Ensure the host plant, usually an oak tree, receives adequate sunlight by thinning the canopy through strategic pruning. Full exposure to sunlight helps in drying out the foliage, making the environment less conducive to fungal development. Additionally, planting trees in open areas with good airflow can prevent the persistent humid conditions that favor mildew outbreaks."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning can help manage the impact of Erysiphe alphitoides by improving air circulation and reducing the density of foliage, thereby creating less favorable conditions for the fungus to thrive. Remove and destroy any affected leaves or branches promptly to stop the spread of the mildew. Prune during dry conditions and disinfect tools between cuts to prevent further transmission of the fungus. Regular thinning and maintaining the overall health of the host tree can significantly help in combating infections."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Erysiphe alphitoides is a species of fungus which causes powdery mildew on oak trees.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Ukraine","Africa","North America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Erysiphe alphitoides"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18248,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cytinus hypocistis is a parasitic plant that primarily depends on its host plants for water and nutrients, so watering directly is not typically necessary. It attaches to the roots of specific host plants like Cistus species, absorbing moisture the host draws from its environment. Therefore, ensure the host plant is in a suitable environment with adequate moisture levels to support both the host and the parasitic plant, and monitor the host plant's watering needs to indirectly support the Cytinus hypocistis."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cytinus hypocistis does not require sunlight for its own photosynthesis, as it is entirely parasitic and derives its energy from its host plant. However, the host plant, typically a Cistus species, will require a suitable sunny environment to thrive. Make sure the host plant is exposed to adequate sunlight, usually full sun or partial shade, depending on the specific requirements of the host species, to ensure it can sufficiently support the Cytinus hypocistis attached to it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not required for Cytinus hypocistis due to its nature as a parasitic plant. However, if managing the plant for scientific or study purposes, removing spent or non-viable flowers can be done to keep the area tidy or to prevent overwhelming its host plant. Since it relies entirely on its host plant for survival, the focus should remain on ensuring the host plant itself is healthy and managed properly, rather than direct pruning of the Cytinus hypocistis itself."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Cytinus","description":"Cytinus hypocistis is an ant-pollinated species of parasitic plant in the family Cytinaceae having four subspecies. It is found primarily in locations that surround the Mediterranean Sea, and is the type for the genus Cytinus. The binomial has been conserved.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern Europe","Northern Africa"],"other_name":["Yellow Cytinus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cytinus hypocistis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18842,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Paeonia anomala, a hardy perennial, prefers moderate watering. It requires well-drained soil to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the roots. Water deeply once a week during dry periods, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Avoid wetting the foliage to minimize the risk of fungal diseases. During the plant's dormancy in winter, reduce watering significantly, only providing it enough moisture to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry. Ensure good drainage to protect the peony during rainy seasons, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paeonia anomala thrives in full sun but can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hot summer climates. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote vigorous blooming and healthy growth. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can prevent stress and dehydration. While the plant can survive in shadier spots, the bloom quality and quantity might be reduced, making adequate sunlight important for the best flowering results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Paeonia anomala involves cutting back the stems after flowering to maintain a neat appearance and encourage better growth next season. After the flowers fade, remove spent blooms to prevent seed production and direct the plant’s energy back into the roots. In late fall, cut the foliage back to about 1 inch above the ground to prevent fungal diseases overwintering. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to maintain a healthy plant structure. Sanitize pruning tools to avoid spreading diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"anomalous peony","description":"Paeonia anomala is a species of herbaceous perennial peony. The vernacular name in Russia is Пион необыча́йный (Pion neobycháynyy) meaning \"anomalous peony\", in Kazakh it is called кәдімгі Таушымылдық (kädimgi Tawşımıldıq) \"common peony\", in Mongolia Ягаан цээнэand (Yagaan tseene) \"pink peony\", and in China 新疆芍药 (xin jiang shao yao), \"Xinjiang peony\". These plants are ½-1 m high, have a thick irregular taproot and thin side roots, and deeply incised leaves, with leaflets themselves divided in fine segments....","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern Europe","Western Siberia","Central Asia"],"other_name":["anomalous peony"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Paeonia anomala"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19147,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fuscospora solandri, commonly known as Black Beech, has moderate water needs. It prefers well-drained soil and should be watered regularly during its establishment phase, which typically lasts for the first two years. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant but benefits from occasional deep watering during dry periods to help maintain its health. Avoid waterlogging the soil, as this can lead to root rot and other fungal issues. Adjust the watering frequency based on the climate and existing rainfall, ensuring that the soil is moist but not soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Black Beech thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers locations where it can receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day, especially during the growing season. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Choosing a planting site with adequate sunlight exposure is crucial to ensure healthy growth and development. In shaded conditions, the tree may experience reduced growth rates and a thinner foliage canopy, which can make it more susceptible to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Fuscospora solandri is generally minimal and mainly requires the removal of dead or damaged branches to maintain tree health and aesthetics. It is best to prune during the tree's dormancy period, late winter to early spring, to minimize stress and potential disease exposure. When pruning, make clean cuts at the branch union and avoid removing more than necessary to maintain the natural shape of the tree. Regularly inspect the tree for any signs of disease or pest damage and address them as needed to ensure vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"New Zealand black beech","description":"Fuscospora solandri, commonly called black beech (Māori: tawhai pango), is a species of southern beech, endemic to New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18646,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Blechnum montanum prefers consistently moist soil, so it's important to keep the substrate damp but not waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly before watering again. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage by using a well-aerated potting mix and containers with drainage holes. In drier climates or indoor settings, increase humidity by misting the leaves or placing a humidifier nearby. During winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant’s growth slows down. Monitoring the soil moisture level is crucial in keeping Blechnum montanum healthy and thriving."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Blechnum montanum thrives in shaded or partially shaded environments, making it ideal for understory planting or indoor situations where direct sunlight is limited. Avoid placing it in direct sunlight as its delicate fronds are prone to scorching and dehydration. Ideally, position the plant where it receives filtered or dappled sunlight, such as near a north or east-facing window. If grown outdoors, ensure it is under the canopy of taller plants or trees for sufficient shade. During cooler months, it can tolerate slightly more light, but always monitor for signs of light stress, such as browning or wilting fronds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Blechnum montanum involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's health and aesthetic appearance. Use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to cut the fronds at their base, near the soil surface. Regular pruning encourages new growth and prevents the plant from becoming too congested. It’s typically sufficient to prune once or twice a year, usually in early spring or late fall. Carefully inspect the plant for any signs of disease or pest infestations during pruning and remove affected areas promptly. This practice helps in sustaining the plant's vigor and encourages lush growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Kiokio","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand","Australia","Chile"],"other_name":["Mountain Kiokio"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Spores","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Blechnum montanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Slightly acidic","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19443,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carpobrotus deliciosus, commonly known as hottentot fig, requires minimal watering due to its succulent nature. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant once every two weeks, ensuring the soil is thoroughly soaked. However, allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In winter, reduce the frequency of watering to once a month, or even less, depending on rainfall and humidity. Be cautious not to overwater, as this plant is drought tolerant and thrives in dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carpobrotus deliciosus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sun per day. It's best to plant this succulent in a location where it can receive ample sunlight to promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight will result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. It's ideal for rockeries, coastal gardens, and sunny slopes where sunlight is abundant. Ensure the plant is not shaded by larger plants or structures to maximize its exposure to sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To maintain the shape and health of Carpobrotus deliciosus, regular pruning is recommended. Trim the plant in early spring before the growing season starts to remove any dead or damaged leaves. If the plant becomes too leggy, cut back the longer stems to encourage bushier growth. Prune lightly throughout the growing season to remove spent flowers and promote continuous blooming. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts just above a node or lateral branch, ensuring a clean wound for the plant to heal quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Delicious Sourfig","description":"Carpobrotus deliciosus (commonly known as sweet Hottentots fig, perdevy, ghaukum, ghounavy) is a succulent perennial of the family Aizoaceae, native to a strip along the south coast of South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Delicious Sourfig"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Carpobrotus deliciosus"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid waterlogging the host plant's roots, as excess moisture can harm both the host and the Tupeia itself. Adjust the lighting based on the plant's response to ensure optimal health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tupeia antarctica involves careful management, as it must be balanced with the health of the host plant. It's advisable to prune after the flowering period to encourage healthy growth and to prevent the Tupeia from overwhelming the host plant. Regular maintenance will help control its semi-parasitic nature and prevent it from dominating any given area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Tupeia is a monotypic genus of semi-parasitic shrubs (mistletoes) which occurs in both the North and South Islands of New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19243,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron tomentosum, commonly known as Labrador tea, prefers moist but well-drained soil conditions. It's best to water this plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. During its growing season, which is typically spring through early fall, maintain consistent moisture by watering thoroughly whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. It's essential to avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and maintain a stable environment for the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron tomentosum thrives in partial shade to full sunlight, making it quite adaptable to different light conditions. However, it tends to perform best in environments where it receives dappled sunlight or partial shade for most of the day. Direct, intense sunlight, especially in the afternoon, can cause leaf burn. Ideally, provide morning sunlight with some afternoon shade. This will ensure the plant gets enough light without the risk of overheating or dehydration. If planted indoors, place it near an east or west-facing window where indirect sunlight is readily available."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron tomentosum is not typically necessary for form, but it can benefit from light trimming to encourage healthy growth and maintain its shape. The best time to prune this plant is in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to prevent potential disease spread. If you're looking to control its size or shape, selectively prune back overgrown branches to a lateral branch or bud. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant’s tissue, and avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"marsh Labrador tea","description":"Rhododendron tomentosum (syn. Deep watering once a week should suffice, allowing the soil to partially dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided, as it can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool during warmer seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Osmanthus heterophyllus thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate full sun but may require some afternoon shade in hotter climates to prevent leaf scorch. For optimal growth, plant it in a location that receives morning sun followed by afternoon shade, ensuring it gets at least four to six hours of sunlight per day. In shadier spots, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, so balancing light exposure according to the climate is crucial for the health and flowering potential of the shrub."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Osmanthus heterophyllus helps to maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. The best time for pruning is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches first, then shape the plant by trimming overgrown sections, making clean cuts just above new leaf buds. This shrub can tolerate heavy pruning if necessary, but always avoid removing more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Direct watering is unnecessary and can lead to unfavorable conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fomitopsis mounceae does not require direct sunlight as it naturally grows on decaying logs within densely shaded forests. In a lab or artificial setting, simulating its natural habitat with ambient light without direct sunlight exposure is ideal. The emphasis should be on maintaining the naturally shaded and moist conditions they favor rather than light intensity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning, in the context of fungi like Fomitopsis mounceae, doesn't apply as it does with traditional plants. Being a fungus, removal or 'pruning' is not part of its care routine. Remove any competing fungi or decaying plant matter carefully if it affects the growth medium or environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Northern Red Belt","description":"Fomitopsis mounceae is a recently isolated species of shelf fungus. It's adapted to dry environments, so it does not require frequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is best to let the top inch of the soil dry out completely between waterings. In winter, reduce the amount of watering significantly, as the plant's growth slows and the moisture requirements are lower."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Teucrium polium thrives in full sun, making it ideal for locations with bright, direct sunlight for most of the day. It should be done after the flowering period ends, usually in late summer or early fall. Trim back the stems by about one-third to encourage bushiness and remove any dead or damaged branches. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19149,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Condea emoryi, commonly known as Desert Lavender, requires moderate watering. During its establishment phase, water it once a week. Once established, reduce the frequency to every two to three weeks, allowing the soil to dry out in between. In its native environment, it thrives with minimal water, so be cautious not to overwater, particularly if it rains in your area. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent root rot. During winter, reduce the watering frequency even further, only watering when you notice signs of stress or wilting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Condea emoryi thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. It is well-suited to arid, sunny environments found in desert landscapes and appreciates the intense sunlight. While it can tolerate some light shade, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If planted indoors or in a more shaded area, ensure it receives adequate light by placing it near a south or west-facing window or considering supplemental grow lights to mimic its natural sunny conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Condea emoryi lightly to maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. Dead or damaged branches should be removed at any time of the year to maintain the plant's health. For shaping purposes, the best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Do not prune more than one-third of the plant at a time to avoid stressing it. Regular pruning encourages healthy branches and a more robust structure, helping it withstand intense sunlight and sporadic winds in its natural habitat."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"desert lavender","description":"Condea emoryi (synonym Hyptis emoryi), the desert lavender, is a large, multi-stemmed shrub species of flowering plant in Lamiaceae, the mint family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Arizona","California","Nevada","Mexico"],"other_name":["desert lavender"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Condea emoryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Monitor the foliage color; pale, leggy growth may indicate insufficient sunlight, while sunburned leaves may suggest too much direct sunlight without sufficient protection."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myrcianthes leucoxyla is best done in late winter or early spring before the onset of new growth. Then, thin out crowded areas to improve airflow and light penetration. Make your cuts just above a leaf node or bud to promote healthy regrowth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18250,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phemeranthus parviflorus, commonly known as Prairie Fameflower, requires minimal watering as it is drought-tolerant. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season in the warmer months, a thorough watering once every two weeks should suffice. Ensure that the pot or garden bed has excellent drainage to prevent root rot, as standing water is detrimental to the plant. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, only providing moisture when the soil is dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phemeranthus parviflorus thrives in full sunlight and requires a minimum of six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to perform best. It is adapted to sunny, dry environments and can tolerate high heat, making it suitable for rock gardens or xeriscaping. In regions with extreme summer temperatures, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. However, insufficient sunlight will result in leggy growth and poor flowering. The plant should be positioned in an area that receives adequate morning and noon sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phemeranthus parviflorus is typically not necessary, but light pruning can be beneficial for maintaining its shape and removing dead or damaged leaves. If needed, prune in early spring before the new growth begins, cutting back any spent flower stalks and removing any unsightly foliage to encourage healthy blooming and growth. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, and take care not to excessively trim healthy foliage that supports the plant's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"prairie fameflower","description":"Phemeranthus parviflorus, commonly called sunbright or prairie fame flower, is a species of flowering plant in the montia family (Montiaceae). It is native to North America, where it is found in the central and eastern United States and northern Mexico. Its natural habitat is in dry, sandy or rocky areas, typically on acidic substrates. Over its extensive range, it is found various communities such as grasslands, open woodlands, glades, mountain slopes, and bluffs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["prairie fameflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phemeranthus parviflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate some morning sun, it’s crucial to protect it from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. The dappled sunlight under trees or a garden setting that offers bright, indirect light is perfect for its growth. If grown indoors, place it near a north-facing window or any area that avoids direct sunlight to mimic its natural habitat. This sunlight regimen helps maintain its lush foliage and promotes healthy blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ourisia macrophylla is relatively straightforward. Trim back any dead or damaged leaves throughout the growing season to maintain the plant’s appearance and health. After the flowering period, remove spent flower stalks to encourage new growth and potentially more blooms. In late fall, cut back the plant to soil level if the foliage has died back after frost. This not only tidies up the plant but also prepares it for the next growing season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18549,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Muehlenbeckia australis prefers consistent moisture, so water it regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, but not waterlogged. It's crucial to ensure good drainage since waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering to support the plant’s active growth period. However, in the dormant months of fall and winter, reduce watering, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Always adjust your watering practices based on the local climate and indoor humidity levels if grown indoors."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Muehlenbeckia australis thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may result in slower growth and a less dense appearance. If grown indoors, place it near a south or east-facing window where it can absorb bright light throughout the day. If outdoor conditions are too shady, consider relocating the plant to a sunnier spot to ensure healthy foliage and vigorous growth. Avoid extreme heat as it can scorch the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Muehlenbeckia australis is essential to maintain its size and shape, as it can grow quite vigorously. Prune it in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Trim back long, unruly vines to encourage bushier growth and remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year to keep the plant healthy. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, and be mindful not to over-prune, which can stress the plant. Regular pruning helps in managing its growth and prevents it from becoming too invasive if planted in the garden."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pohuehue","description":"Muehlenbeckia australis, large-leaved muehlenbeckia or pohuehue, is a prostrate or climbing plant native to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Pohuehue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Muehlenbeckia australis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19736,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia rigidula, also known as Blackbrush acacia, is drought-tolerant and well-suited to arid climates. It prefers infrequent but deep watering, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it's important to ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. During periods of prolonged drought or extreme heat, you may need to increase the frequency of watering, but generally, this plant does well with minimal water once established in the right environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Blackbrush acacia thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. It is highly adaptable to sunny, dry environments and cannot tolerate full shade. Full sun exposure is essential for optimal growth and flowering. If grown indoors or in a less sunny area, it may require additional light sources such as grow lights. When planting outdoors, choose a spot with unobstructed sunlight throughout the day, as this will ensure the plant remains healthy and vigorous."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Blackbrush acacia is generally minimal and should be done primarily to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, clean tools to make clean cuts and avoid tearing the branches. Remove crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Be cautious of the plant's thorns during pruning. Maintain a natural shape rather than imposing a uniform structure, as the plant thrives when allowed to grow in its natural form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blackbrush Acacia","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Blackbrush Acacia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia rigidula"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19641,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"When caring for Hypericum tenuifolium, it's important to water it regularly, especially during dry spells to maintain consistent soil moisture; however, ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging. This plant prefers moderate moisture levels and can tolerate some drought once established, but for optimal growth, avoid letting the soil completely dry out between waterings. To avoid overwatering, allow the top inch of the soil to dry before watering again. Be particularly mindful during the summer months when evaporation rates are higher and the plant's water needs may increase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypericum tenuifolium thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure robust flowering and healthy growth. In regions with intense afternoon sun, providing some light shade can prevent leaf scorching. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but flowering might be reduced in lower light conditions. For optimal blooms and to maintain a dense habit, a location with morning sunlight and afternoon shade may be suitable, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum tenuifolium should be done annually or biannually to maintain its size and encourage bushier growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead or damaged stems to enhance the plant's overall health. You can shape the shrub according to your preference, but avoid cutting more than one-third of the plant at once, as this can stress the plant. Pruning spent flowers can also encourage a longer flowering season. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sandhill St. John's-wort","description":"Hypericum tenuifolium, known as Atlantic St. John's-wort and sandhill St. John's-wort, is a species of flowering plant in the St. John's wort family, Hypericaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19445,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Empodium plicatum, a bulbous plant native to South Africa, has adapted well to dry conditions. It prefers to be watered sparingly, especially during its dormancy period in the summer months. During its active growth phase in the fall and winter, moderate watering is recommended, ensuring the soil is well-drained to prevent bulb rot. It thrives best when water is provided only once the topsoil has dried out. Avoid letting the plant sit in water and reduce watering significantly once the foliage starts to yellow, indicating the onset of dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Empodium plicatum requires bright light to thrive, reflecting its natural habitat in sunny, open areas of South Africa. Ideally, it should be positioned in a location where it can receive full sun for most of the day. If growing indoors or under shade, ensure it's near a window or a spot with sufficient light to mimic these conditions. However, although it prefers full sun, providing some light afternoon shade may benefit in extremely hot climates to prevent scorching, especially during its active growing periods."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Empodium plicatum is relatively straightforward since it is a bulb plant. Once the flowering period is over and the foliage begins to yellow, usually at the beginning of their dormant phase, you can trim back any dead or dying leaves. This not only helps maintain the plant’s health by preventing the risk of disease but also tidies its appearance. Avoid removing healthy foliage while it's still green since it helps with photosynthesis, storing energy in the bulb for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Plough Star","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Plough Star"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Empodium plicatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18446,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Micranthes petiolaris, also known as Cliff Saxifrage, prefers consistently moist soil but should not be left to sit in waterlogged conditions as this can cause root rot. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to ensure the soil remains damp but not soggy. In pots, ensure the containers have good drainage to prevent water buildup. During winter dormancy, reduce watering as the plant will not absorb as much moisture. Check the top inch of soil to determine if it needs watering, and always allow it to dry slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Micranthes petiolaris thrives in partial to full shade environments, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens or shaded areas. It requires protection from intense direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, as this can scorch the leaves and hinder growth. When grown indoors, place it in a location that receives filtered or indirect light. Ensuring the plant receives dapples of sunlight through leaves can mimic its natural habitat and help promote healthy growth without exposing it to damaging direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Micranthes petiolaris is generally minimal but beneficial for promoting healthy growth and flowering. Remove any dead or damaged leaves from the plant as they appear. After the flowering period, it's good practice to remove spent flower stalks to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production. This can encourage more robust foliage growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. In the fall, some gardeners may choose to cut back the plant lightly to prepare it for winter dormancy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cliff Saxifrage","description":"Micranthes petiolaris, commonly known as cliff saxifrage, is a species of flowering plant in the saxifrage family. It is native to the Southern Appalachian Mountains where it is found on exposed boulders and rocky seeps, often at high elevation. It is a perennial that produces small white flowers with yellow spots in the summer.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Cliff Saxifrage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Micranthes petiolaris"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade will protect it from scorching. When growing indoors or in lower light conditions, providing bright, indirect light will help maintain healthy growth and vibrant foliage. Adequate sunlight is essential for blooming and overall plant vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Metrosideros perforata is generally done to manage its size and encourage bushier growth. It prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. Water deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry, allowing the water to reach the deeper root zone. It's important to water early in the morning or late in the afternoon to reduce evaporation. During its active growing period in spring and summer, regular watering is necessary, while in fall and winter, watering can be reduced. Always consider environmental factors like temperature and humidity, adjusting your watering schedule accordingly to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Malva thuringiaca thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Full sunlight ensures robust growth and prolific blooming. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from severe heat stress or wilting. If planted in partial shade, this plant may not bloom as profusely, so it's essential to find a balance if full sun is not consistently available. Ensure it's situated in a spot with morning sunlight and some protection from the harsh afternoon sun, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malva thuringiaca is essential to encourage bushier growth and more abundant flowering. This should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Trim back any dead or damaged stems to their base to maintain plant vigor. You can also deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to prolong flowering and promote new blooms. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, cut back about one-third of the growth to encourage a more compact form. After flowering, perform a more substantial prune to tidy up the plant and prepare it for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eastern Tree-mallow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central Europe","Eastern Europe"],"other_name":["Eastern Tree-mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rust","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Malva thuringiaca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In containers, ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot while maintaining adequate moisture levels, and reduce watering frequency during cooler months when the plant's growth slows."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prionium serratum thrives in full sun to partial shade, preferring bright conditions to grow robust and healthy. Late winter or early spring is the best time for pruning if shaping is required. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts neat and to prevent potential infections. Avoid cutting back into old wood, as new growth typically emerges only from more recent growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Palmiet","description":"Prionium serratum, the palmiet, is a robust, evergreen, semiaquatic, rhizomatous flowering plant growing to 2 m (6 ft 7 in) in height. It is best pruned in winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Remove dead or weak stems, and trim remaining stems back to a pair of healthy buds. This variety typically blooms on new wood, so annual pruning helps promote a healthy structure and maximizes bloom production. Regular pruning will also help contain its spread and keep it vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Traveller's joy","description":"Clematis brachiata, commonly known as traveller's joy, is a hardy, deciduous South African liana belonging to the Ranunculaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Africa"],"other_name":["Traveller's joy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Clematis brachiata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to find a balance; ideally, place the plant near a window with filtered light. If natural light is insufficient, especially in low-light environments, consider using artificial grow lights to supplement its needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pothos chinensis is beneficial for maintaining its health and encouraging bushier growth. Trim the stems to control the size and shape of the plant, removing any dead or damaged leaves as you find them. Pruning can also help prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears and make cuts just above a leaf node for optimal results. It's best to prune during the growing season, in spring or early summer, to give the plant time to recover and produce new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Chinese Pothos","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Chinese Pothos"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pothos chinensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adjust the watering frequency depending on the season, reducing it during the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. In its native habitat, it can tolerate periods of drought, so it’s best to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Funastrum heterophyllum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It can adapt to various lighting situations but prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with intense, scorching sun, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. In shadier conditions, the plant might not bloom as profusely but will still grow. Adjust the placement according to the local climate, ensuring that the plant receives enough light to grow healthily and produce its characteristic twining vines."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Funastrum heterophyllum is mainly done to control its size and manage its twining growth habit. It’s best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. Trim back any excessively long vines to maintain the plant’s desired shape. Regular pruning can also encourage fuller, bushier growth by stimulating new shoots. However, be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hartweg's climbing milkweed","description":"Funastrum cynanchoides (formerly called Sarcostemma cynanchoides), also known as fringed twinevine, twining milkweed or climbing milkweed, is a perennial plant in the family Apocynaceae that grows twining through other plants in the Mojave Desert and Sonoran Desert. It has milky sap and smells pungent. It is similar to Funastrum hirtellum.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Hartweg's climbing milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Funastrum heterophyllum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it enjoys moist conditions, ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. In container growing, check more frequently, as pots can dry faster. Regular maintenance can also involve removing any overlapping growth to ensure adequate air circulation, minimizing fungal issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"primrose monkeyflower","description":"Erythranthe primuloides is a Western United States perennial plant in the lopseed family (Phrymaceae), known by the common name primrose monkeyflower. At the end of the flowering season, perform a more significant prune to reshape the plant and remove any dead or damaged branches. This routine maintenance will help maintain the plant’s health and appearance. During early spring, a light trim can help remove any frost-damaged portions, preparing the plant for the upcoming growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"South American mock vervain","description":"Verbena aristigera (syns. It is native to Bolivia, southern Brazil, northern Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19152,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia tortilis, commonly known as the umbrella thorn acacia, is adapted to hot, arid environments and therefore requires minimal watering once established. In its native habitat, it thrives on seasonal rainfall and can withstand prolonged dry periods. During its initial growth phase, water it sparingly to help it develop a deep and self-sufficient root system. Once established, it should only be watered occasionally during extended dry spells. Overwatering can be detrimental, causing root rot and other issues, so it is crucial to ensure the soil dries out between waterings. Ideal soil is well-draining, reducing the risk of water-logging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vachellia tortilis is well-suited to bright, sunny conditions. In its native arid regions of Africa and the Middle East, it thrives in full sunlight and high temperatures. To mimic these conditions, ensure it receives full sun exposure, ideally at least six to eight hours per day. It is tolerant of heat and can even adapt to more extreme sunlight levels without damage. If grown in less arid regions, ensure its location has adequate sun exposure to avoid weakened growth or sparse foliage. Adjusting its placement according to sunlight access is essential for its health and growth vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vachellia tortilis should primarily focus on maintaining its naturally beautiful shape and removing any dead or diseased branches. This can support its health and structural integrity. Since this plant grows slowly, pruning is usually minimal. The best time to prune is during its dormancy period, typically late winter to early spring. Remove suckers and any crossing or rubbing branches to promote good air circulation and sunlight penetration. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize the risk of infection. This approach helps maintain the tree's characteristic flat-topped canopy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"umbrella thorn","description":"Vachellia tortilis, widely known as Acacia tortilis but attributed by APG III to the Vachellia genus, is the umbrella thorn acacia, also known as umbrella thorn and Israeli babool, a medium to large canopied tree native primarily to the savanna and Sahel of Africa (especially Sudan), but also occurring in the Middle East.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa","Middle East"],"other_name":["umbrella thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia tortilis"],"soil":["Sandy","Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It needs plenty of sunlight to develop its vibrant foliage and produce its attractive flowers. Ideally, you should place it in a location that receives several hours of direct sunlight daily, especially during the morning. However, in extremely hot climates, offering some afternoon shade can protect it from excessive sun and heat. If grown indoors, a bright spot near a south or east-facing window would be most beneficial. Ensuring it receives the right balance of sunlight will promote healthy and robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brachyglottis kirkii should be done to maintain its shape and remove dead or damaged growth, which will enhance its overall appearance and health. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back any overly long or untidy stems to encourage bushier and more compact growth. Also, remove any dead or diseased leaves or stems promptly to prevent the spread of diseases. Regular pruning can help this plant maintain its vigorous growth and lovely appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and reduce the risk of harm."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kirk's tree daisy","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Kirk's tree daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Caterpillars"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Brachyglottis kirkii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19248,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalanchoe × houghtonii prefers to be watered deeply but infrequently. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings, as this plant is highly susceptible to root rot from overwatering. During the growing season, water every 2-3 weeks, adjusting based on the humidity and temperature conditions. In the winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Always ensure the pot has excellent drainage to avoid standing water at the base, which can lead to fungal issues and root decay."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalanchoe × houghtonii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Exposure to around 4-6 hours per day is ideal to maintain its vibrant foliage coloration and compact growth habit. Direct sunlight during the harsh midday hours can scorch the leaves, so filtered light or morning sun is preferable. If grown indoors, place it near an east or south-facing window. During winter months, when the sun is less intense, it may tolerate increased direct exposure. Rotate the plant occasionally to ensure even light distribution and growth on all sides."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe × houghtonii is generally only necessary to remove dead or withered leaves and stems, which can occur naturally over time. This helps keep the plant looking tidy and encourages healthy new growth. Pruning can also help control the plant's size, especially if it becomes leggy or starts to encroach upon neighboring plants. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid damaging the plant, and prune slightly above a node to promote branching. Prune during the spring marking the beginning of its growing season for the best results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alligator plant","description":"Kalanchoe × houghtonii is a hybrid between K. daigremontiana and K. delagoensis. It is often confused with K. daigremontiana which has strongly cordate to auriculate or even peltate leaves, while the leaves of K. × houghtonii are narrower and the leaf base is attenuate, cuneate to weakly cordate or auriculate.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Madagascar"],"other_name":["Alligator plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Leaf cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Kalanchoe × houghtonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, it's important to maintain consistent moisture levels, particularly in sandy or well-drained soils, to support optimal growth. Avoid overwatering, as Agalinis lanceolata does not thrive in waterlogged soils. Deep watering is recommended, allowing the soil to become partly dry between waterings. In drier areas, consider mulching to retain soil moisture. However, during its dormant period, significantly reduce watering, allowing natural rainfall to suffice unless conditions are extremely dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agalinis lanceolata thrives in full sun or light, partial shade, making best use of 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This level of sunlight supports the plant's flowering and overall growth. While it can tolerate some shade, insufficient light may lead to fewer blooms and leggy growth. If planted in areas with hotter, intense sun, some afternoon shade might protect it from excessive heat stress. In shaded environments, ensure it receives at least a few hours of morning sunlight to optimize blooming. Position the plant away from taller plants and structures that could significantly shadow it throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agalinis lanceolata is not typically necessary for maintenance, as this plant naturally maintains a desirable size and shape. However, if desired, you can deadhead spent flowers to encourage a tidier appearance and possibly stimulate a more extended blooming period. Cutting the plant back by a third after flowering can help prevent legginess and encourage denser growth for the next season. Be cautious not to cut the plant too aggressively, especially late in the growing season, as this can affect its ability to overwinter successfully. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Agalinis lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18951,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fritillaria imperialis, also known as Crown Imperial, requires regular watering during its growing season, especially during dry spells, to maintain continuously moist soil. Avoid waterlogging as this could rot the bulbs. Once the flowers begin to fade, gradually reduce the frequency of watering, and by late summer, let the soil become dry to encourage dormancy, respecting its natural cycle. Refrain from watering during the dormant phase, usually in late summer, to prevent bulb rot. A balance of sufficient moisture during growth and dryness during dormancy ensures healthy growth and flowering the next year."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fritillaria imperialis thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day during its growing season. Full sun helps the plant develop sturdy stems and vibrant flowers, although in hotter climates, a bit of afternoon shade can prevent excessive drying of soil and leaves. Ensure the plant isn’t in complete shade as insufficient light can hinder flowering. Providing the right balance of sunlight supports a healthy growth cycle and optimal blooming, integral to its ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fritillaria imperialis involves removing spent flowers to prevent seed formation and conserving energy for the bulb. After the blooming period, cut back wilted flower stalks near ground level. Allow the foliage to die back naturally as this is essential for photosynthesis, storing energy for next season’s growth. Completely remove the dead leaves once they have fully withered and turned yellow or brown, as this signals their energy transfer to the bulb is complete. After initial inoculation, water the substrate to keep it damp, similar to soil that is always moist but not waterlogged. Maintain high humidity with frequent misting, ensuring water droplets do not accumulate overly, as too much standing water can hinder growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panaeolus antillarum does not require sunlight like traditional plants since mushrooms do not photosynthesize. Instead, they thrive in areas with indirect light or dim conditions. Providing bright but indirect light can support fruiting, as total darkness might suppress their visible growth. Avoid direct sunlight as it can dry out the substrate. If growing indoors or in controlled environments, ambient room lighting or low wattage grow lights mimicking natural day-night cycles can suffice for appropriate growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Panaeolus antillarum is a mushroom and not a green plant, it does not require pruning. However, managing its growth involves controlling the substrate conditions and sometimes clearing away any competing molds or non-beneficial fungi. When harvesting, it is recommended to carefully twist and pull mature fruiting bodies as they appear, rather than cutting them, to avoid damage to the mycelium. This method allows the substrate to continue supporting future flushes if conditions remain optimal."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Caribbean","Tropical regions"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Panaeolus antillarum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Organic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly examine the plant and perform light pruning as necessary, especially when the plant is dormant in winter. Avoid over-pruning as orchids are relatively slow growers, and excessive removal can stress the plant. Ensuring enough light without overexposure will aid in healthy growth and increase the chances of successful blooming during its flowering period."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pterostylis trullifolia is minimal, but necessary to maintain plant health. Additionally, any dead or yellowing leaves can be carefully trimmed away to improve airflow and overall aesthetics. Always use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to avoid the spread of disease. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant, particularly during its dormant phase."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"trowel-leaved greenhood","description":"Pterostylis trullifolia, commonly known as the trowel-leaved greenhood, is an orchid species endemic to New Zealand. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. You should water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, though reducing water in winter is advisable as the plant's growth slows down. Direct sunlight can scorch its leaves, so placing it near a east or west-facing window where it can receive ample indirect light is ideal. If the plant does not receive enough light, it may become leggy and lose its lower leaves. In low-light situations, consider supplementing with grow lights to provide the necessary light levels. Gradually acclimate the plant to its lighting conditions, especially if moving it from a darker area to a brighter one, to prevent leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus subpisocarpa helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. The best time to prune is during its active growth period in the spring or early summer. Start by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged leaves and branches using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. You can also trim back any leggy or overly long branches to promote a bushier appearance. Be cautious not to remove more than a third of the plant at once, as this can stress the plant. Regular pruning can also help control the size of the plant, preventing it from becoming too large."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese Superb Fig","description":"Ficus subpisocarpa (called 笔管榕 in China and 雀榕 in Taiwan) is a species of small deciduous tree native to Japan, China, Taiwan and southeast Asia to the Moluccas (Ceram). Two subspecies are recognised. Terrestrial or hemiepiphytic, it reaches a height of 7 m (23 ft). Ants predominantly of the genus Crematogaster have been recorded living in stem cavities. Ficus subpisocarpa is pollinated by Platyscapa ishiiana (Agaonidae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan","Japan","China"],"other_name":["Japanese Superb Fig"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus subpisocarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19154,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenothera rubricaulis, commonly known as redstem evening primrose, prefers moderately dry soil conditions.
